Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: A User-Discovery, Hypothesis-Driven Exploration of Potential Scaling and Sustainability of Innovations in Water Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to engage in a hypothesis-driven, customer-discovery process to inform the scalability and sustainability of educational innovations in the field of hydrology and water resources education. The HydroViz educational innovation was developed as a set of web-based, active-learning modules for undergraduate hydrology and water resources education with extensive use of water data and modeling resources. The project responds to the increasing calls by the water education communities for a broad reform in hydrologic education as a requisite for making significant advances in the theory and practices of water resources engineering and earth sciences. While the immediate end users of the potential development is in the field of water resources and hydrology, the outcomes of this I-Corps L effort will have an impact on the broader community of users who can benefit from place-based education and who can take advantage of geospatial technologies, web-based resources, and scientific data sharing. The project will also contribute to resolving lasting challenges that confront digital learning and cyber-education efforts that often fail to achieve fully scalable and sustainable outcomes.

The project will produce knowledge on how to scale and sustain educational innovations that are presented in the form of digital learning resources. The hypothesis, developed based on classroom implementation and assessment data, as well as feedback from instructors, indicates that there is a user need for developments such as those initiated in this project and that there is an opportunity for the project to engage in a scaling effort that is guided by a rigorous process of customer discovery and hypothesis validation. A hypothesized scalability and sustainability solution is to establish a general platform for the learning modules to connect to and interoperate with community-based hydrologic data and model sharing resources, and thus provide a user capability by which independent users can develop their own modules. The envisioned solution will go through a hypothesis validation and customer discovery process as part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project conducted a customer-discovery process to inform the scalability and sustainability of educational innovations in the field of hydrology and water resources engineering education. 

Our project lead to the formulation of a set of value propositions and customer segments for potential adoption of data and modeling-driven learning innovations in the field of water resources engineering. Our effort in this I-Corps L program also contributed to advancing the knowledge on how engaging in a hypothesis-driven discovery of the end-users and their anticipated needs can inform developmental strategies and lead to scalable and sustained impact beyond the typically short life cycle of the initial development. 

Outcomes on Identification of Value Propositions:

(a) Access to modular resources on data analytics and modeling that can be efficiently adapted into current hydrology curriculum
(b) Expedite (time and effort) the development of new learning and training resources
(c) Facilitate sharing and discovery of learning resources
(d) Provide training material in water resources that are time saving, and intergare data and modeling skills, engineering soft skills, and design standards and codes
(e) Increase revenue via new digital learning resources

Outcomes on Identification of Customer Segments:

(a) Academia: University instructors looking for innovative hydrology teaching resources (user & decision maker)
(b) Training Managers in Engineering Firms (decision maker & buyer)
(c) Publishers: Acquisition specialists at publishing firms (decision maker & buyer)

Outcomes on Motivators for Using Innovative Teaching Material in Water Resources Engineering

While important, presumably obvious incentives such as program accreditation and performance evaluations do not seem to be predominant factors. Instead, the driving force, for those who are showing initiative, seems to be personal disposition. Two factors that were observed to influence one’s tendency to participate in innovative strategies were instructor experience and instructors’ priorities, i.e., research or teaching. Achievement and self-efficacy play a large role in instructors’ decisions to adopt new learning material. Attributes of the learning innovation also plays a major role in such decisions as explained in the next section on adoption challenges. 

Outcomes on Identifying Challenges in Utilizing Innovative Educational Materials

There are many challenges expressed by the community when it comes to developing and utilizing innovative materials in education. These issues have been summarized into 5 categories: time, steep learning-curves, refurbishing requirements, structure and format of material, and sharing. The importance and relevance of each of these challenges were further developed as part of our project.


While the immediate end users of our project were concentrated in the field of water resources and hydrology, the outcomes of this I-Corps L effort have implications for broader community of users who benefit from place-based education. The project also contributes to resolving lasting challenges that confront digital learning and cyber-education efforts that often fail to achieve fully scalable and sustainable outcomes. Our project also informs other users such as practicing young engineers for professional development, and publishing companies who look for digital or online new learning resources.
